trackTitle: Excel, MIS and VBA Automation (Ultimate Professional Track)
description: A master-level Excel roadmap combining corporate MIS skills with VBA automation, macros, custom functions and automated reporting for high-impact analyst and MIS roles.

institute.name: Coder & AccoTax
institute.author: Sukanta Hui
institute.location: 25(10/A) Shibtala Road, PO – N. C. Pukur, Barrackpore, West Bengal, India

segments.title: Segment 1 - Excel and MIS Foundation (Recap + Alignment)
segments.summary: Align students to a common level of Excel and MIS understanding before entering automation and advanced workflows.

modules.title: Excel and MIS Skills Recap
topics: Quick recap of formulas, lookups and pivots used in MIS
Review of data cleaning, validation and basic dashboards
Revisiting Power Query and Power Pivot concepts briefly
Identifying pain points suitable for automation (manual repetitive tasks)
Setting up Excel and macro settings safely (trusted locations, macro security)
Practice Session
Readiness Quiz
learningOutcomes: Refresh key Excel and MIS concepts required for automation work
Identify which workflows are best candidates for VBA automation
Configure Excel environment safely for working with macros
modules.summary: Ensure all learners are ready for VBA by revising core Excel and MIS skills.
miniProjects: Mini Project: Document one real or hypothetical manual MIS process suitable for automation
useCases: Transitioning from manual report making to automated workflows
Clarifying where VBA will add the most value
careerSkills: Understanding security basics for macro-enabled files
commonMistakes: Trying to automate processes that are not yet stable or well-defined
Ignoring macro security and file trust issues
references: Articles on choosing processes for automation
teachingTips: Ask students to talk to working professionals about manual Excel pain points.
Highlight the difference between one-time tasks and recurring candidates for automation.
preReading: Basic to advanced Excel and MIS concepts (from previous tracks)

modules.title: Macro Recorder and Basic VBA Concepts
topics: Recording simple macros from user actions
Understanding absolute vs relative recording
Viewing and exploring recorded VBA code in the editor
Structure of a VBA module, procedure and comments
Basic edits to recorded macros (changing ranges, values, messages)
Assigning macros to buttons and shapes in worksheets
Macro-enabled workbooks vs standard workbooks
Practice These Topics
Quick Check Quiz
learningOutcomes: Record and run basic macros to automate repetitive tasks
Interpret simple recorded VBA code structures
Attach macros to user interface elements like buttons
modules.summary: Start automation with the macro recorder and gain familiarity with the VBA environment.
miniProjects: Mini Project: Record and refine a macro for standard report formatting (headers, borders, print setup)
useCases: Speeding up standard report preparation steps
careerSkills: Using macro recording as a bridge to understanding VBA
Implementing small automation without full coding
commonMistakes: Relying only on recorder without understanding limitations
Recording macros with unclean selections and unnecessary steps
teachingTips: Demonstrate ugly vs clean recorded macros and refactor together.
Encourage students to narrate what they are automating while recording.
preReading: Excel and MIS Skills Recap module

segments.title: Segment 2 - Core VBA Programming for Excel
segments.summary: Learn VBA as a programming language to control Excel objects, write logic and work with data programmatically.

modules.title: VBA Language Basics and Excel Object Model
topics: VBA editor tour: project explorer, properties window, code pane, immediate window
Variables, data types and constants in VBA
If, ElseIf, Select Case, For, For Each, Do loops in VBA
Working with the Excel object model: Application, Workbook, Worksheet, Range
Referencing ranges: Range, Cells, UsedRange, named ranges
Message boxes (MsgBox) and input boxes (InputBox)
Writing clean procedures: indentation, naming and comments
Practice These Topics
Test Your Skill
learningOutcomes: Write simple VBA procedures using variables and control structures
Navigate and work with the Excel object model at a basic level
Display information and interact with users via MsgBox and InputBox
modules.summary: Move from recorded macros to hand-written VBA logic using core language constructs and objects.
miniProjects: Mini Project: Build a utility macro that cleans and formats a raw data sheet programmatically
useCases: Building small helper tools for daily Excel tasks
careerSkills: Communicating with non-technical stakeholders using simple dialogs
commonMistakes: Hard-coding sheet names and ranges without flexibility
Ignoring variable declarations and causing type-related bugs
teachingTips: Connect VBA structures to students' knowledge of other languages if any.
Use step-through debugging to show code execution line by line.
preReading: Macro Recorder and Basic VBA Concepts module

modules.title: Automating Data Tasks with VBA
topics: Looping through rows and columns to process data
Finding last used row and last used column safely
Copying, pasting and clearing data using VBA
Working with Tables (ListObjects) via VBA (basic operations)
Applying formulas via VBA and converting to values when needed
Automating data validation set-up and error-proofing via VBA
Practical examples: auto-clean, auto-format, auto-summarize routines
Practice These Topics
Quick Check Quiz
learningOutcomes: Implement loops to process data in large ranges
Automate common list and table operations programmatically
Create robust routines for recurring data preparation
modules.summary: Use VBA to handle large and repetitive data tasks reliably and quickly.
miniProjects: Mini Project: Create a macro that imports, cleans and prepares a raw dump for MIS pivots in one click
useCases: Automating daily or weekly data preparation routines
Reducing manual errors in recurring clean-up tasks
careerSkills: Designing robust automation flows for data-heavy work
Writing maintainable and reusable VBA procedures
commonMistakes: Assuming fixed ranges instead of dynamically detecting sizes
Not testing automation on varied data scenarios
references: VBA examples for data loops and automation
Articles on best practices for Excel VBA automation
teachingTips: Start with manual pseudo-code, then convert to VBA.
Encourage students to test scripts on copied sheets to avoid data loss.
preReading: VBA Language Basics and Excel Object Model module

modules.title: Writing User-Defined Functions (UDFs) in VBA
topics: Difference between Sub procedures and Function procedures
Creating custom worksheet functions using VBA
Handling arguments, optional parameters and validation in functions
Returning results and working with different data types
Practical UDF examples: custom rounding, specialised text or date calculations
Limitations and considerations for UDFs (performance, volatility)
Documenting and sharing UDFs within a team
Practice These Topics
Quick Check Quiz
learningOutcomes: Write custom worksheet functions to extend Excel capabilities
Use UDFs to encapsulate repeated logic cleanly
Share and document UDFs responsibly in team environments
modules.summary: Build your own reusable functions for domain-specific calculations in Excel.
miniProjects: Mini Project: Build a small library of 3–5 UDFs useful for HR, Finance or Sales scenarios
useCases: Implementing specialised business rules not supported by built-in functions
Simplifying complex worksheet formulas using UDFs
careerSkills: Extending Excel to meet custom organisational needs
commonMistakes: Writing UDFs that depend on fixed cells instead of arguments
Creating volatile or slow UDFs that impact performance
references: Examples of useful UDFs for business use
teachingTips: Ask students to identify repeated formula patterns suitable for UDFs.
Emphasize clear naming and comments for all UDFs.
preReading: Automating Data Tasks with VBA module

segments.title: Segment 3 - User Experience and Report Automation
segments.summary: Create user-friendly automation with forms, controlled interfaces and end-to-end report generation flows.

modules.title: UserForms and Interactive Tools in VBA
topics: Introduction to UserForms and controls (text boxes, combo boxes, buttons, etc.)
Designing simple forms for data entry and parameter selection
Loading and saving data between forms and worksheets
Validating inputs inside forms and showing error messages
Creating wizards (step-by-step forms) for complex tasks
Practical examples: input form for new employee or transaction
Practice These Topics
Quick Check Quiz
learningOutcomes: Design and implement UserForms for controlled data input
Connect UserForm actions to worksheet operations
Build simple wizard-like experiences for complex tasks
modules.summary: Build professional user interfaces on top of Excel automation for non-technical users.
miniProjects: Mini Project: Create a UserForm-driven data entry system for a small HR or inventory use case
useCases: Guided data entry tools for non-Excel experts
Reducing direct interaction with raw sheets for end users
careerSkills: Designing user-friendly Excel tools for teams
Bridging gap between raw Excel and application-like experience
commonMistakes: Overcomplicating forms with too many fields at once
Not handling invalid inputs or missing fields gracefully
references: Examples of Excel tools using forms
teachingTips: Encourage low-fidelity design on paper before building forms.
Focus on a few well-designed forms rather than too many small ones.
preReading: Writing User-Defined Functions (UDFs) in VBA module

modules.title: Automated Report Generation and Distribution
topics: Automating data refresh (Power Query refresh + pivot refresh via VBA)
Generating standard reports with fixed layouts from templates
Looping through segments (e.g., region, branch, salesperson) to generate multiple reports
Exporting reports to PDF or separate workbooks automatically (where permitted)
Creating log sheets to track automation runs and errors
Scheduling automation using external tools or guidance (conceptual)
Practice These Topics
Quick Check Quiz
learningOutcomes: Create one-click or minimal-click report generation routines
Handle batch report creation for multiple entities
Implement basic logging for automated processes
modules.summary: Automate repetitive reporting cycles and support scaled MIS distribution.
miniProjects: Mini Project: Build an automated monthly report generator for branches or departments
useCases: Monthly, quarterly and annual automated reporting cycles
Creating hundreds of similar reports for multiple units with one macro
careerSkills: Designing robust and scalable reporting automations
Understanding constraints and governance around automated outputs
commonMistakes: Not handling errors or interruptions during automation
Hard-coding paths and file names without flexibility
references: Guides on automating refresh and export tasks in Excel
teachingTips: Discuss responsible automation: testing and backup before deployment.
Encourage students to think about auditability and traceability.
preReading: UserForms and Interactive Tools in VBA module

modules.title: VBA Best Practices, Debugging and Maintenance
topics: Using the Immediate window, breakpoints and stepping for debugging
Error handling with On Error, structured patterns and logging messages
Writing reusable procedures and modular code
Naming conventions for variables, procedures and modules
Documentation practices: comments, change logs and user guides
Handing over automation to others: packaging, explaining and training
Practice These Topics
Quick Check Quiz
learningOutcomes: Debug and troubleshoot VBA code systematically
Write maintainable, well-structured VBA projects
Prepare automated solutions for handover and long-term use
modules.summary: Move from just making automation to maintaining and supporting it professionally.
miniProjects: Mini Project: Take an existing automation and refactor it for clarity, error handling and documentation
useCases: Supporting Excel-based tools in a corporate environment
Improving reliability and longevity of automation solutions
careerSkills: Professional-level debugging and maintenance of VBA solutions
Working as the 'Excel automation expert' in teams
commonMistakes: Ignoring error handling and letting macros crash silently
Writing long, monolithic procedures that are hard to understand

Defining requirements, scope and success criteria with sample stakeholders
